title: How to make a mummy - Len Bloch

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the body's cells after someone dies?

options.label: B
options.text: The body's natural digestive enzymes stop working, but the enzymes that break down old structures continue to operate.

options.label: C
options.text: The tissues can no longer renew themselves.

options.label: D
options.text: They are replaced by new cells.

multiple-choice.question: Why did the ancient Egyptians start the mummification process by hammering a spike into the skull?

options.label: B
options.text: To determine the cause of death.

options.label: C
options.text: To prevent the brain from decaying by flushing it out and pouring tree resin into the skull.

multiple-choice.question: What was used to prevent further decomposition of the brain?

options.label: D
options.text: A mixture of soda ash and baking soda.

multiple-choice.question: What is natron?

options.label: A
options.text: A naturally occurring salt that can prevent decay by killing bacteria and preventing the body's natural digestive enzymes from working.

options.label: B
options.text: A mixture of soda ash and baking soda that has these properties.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of tree resin used to preserve bodies.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of oil used to massage the body.

multiple-choice.question: What was done to the visceral organs in ancient Egyptian mummification?

options.label: A
options.text: They were left in the body.

options.label: B
options.text: They were treated with tree resin.

options.label: C
options.text: They were replaced with artificial organs.

options.label: D
options.text: They were removed and placed in jars filled with natron to prevent decay.

multiple-choice.question: What happened to the body after it was washed clean to disinfect the skin?

options.label: B
options.text: It was set in a bed of natron for about 35 days to prevent further decay.

options.label: C
options.text: It was placed in a series of nested coffins.

options.label: D
options.text: It was poured with tree resin.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of mummification?

options.label: A
options.text: To tax the body as salted fish.

options.label: B
options.text: To determine the cause of death.

options.label: C
options.text: To preserve the body for eternity.

options.label: D
options.text: To prevent decay and maintain the body's structure by using natron and other methods.

multiple-choice.question: What can scientists do with mummies?

options.label: A
options.text: They can determine the age of the mummy.

options.label: C
options.text: They can perform autopsies to determine the cause of death.

multiple-choice.question: What did scientists discover from mummies that was new information?

options.label: A
options.text: The ancient Egyptians were successful at evading decay.

options.label: B
options.text: Air pollution was a serious problem in ancient Egypt.

multiple-choice.question: What is inevitable, like death and taxes?

title: Can you solve the famously difficult green-eyed logic puzzle? - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What was the condition set by the dictator for the content creator to visit the island and speak to the prisoners?

options.label: A
options.text: The content creator could only make one statement and had to tell the prisoners a new fact.

options.label: B
options.text: The content creator could only make one statement and could not tell the prisoners a new fact.

options.label: C
options.text: The content creator had to stay on the island with the prisoners.

options.label: D
options.text: The content creator had to leave the island immediately after speaking to the prisoners.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the content creator's statement to the prisoners, "At least one of you has green eyes"?

options.label: A
options.text: The prisoners were immediately released from the island.

options.label: B
options.text: The prisoners were left confused and did not know what to do.

options.label: C
options.text: The prisoners were able to figure out their own eye colors and leave the island on the hundredth morning after the content creator's visit.

options.label: D
options.text: The prisoners were able to leave the island on the first night after the content creator's visit.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept coined by philosopher David Lewis that is relevant to the situation on the island?
What was the key to the prisoners being able to figure out their own eye colors and leave the island?

options.label: A
options.text: The content creator's statement that at least one of them had green eyes.

options.label: B
options.text: The prisoners' ability to communicate with each other.

options.label: C
options.text: The prisoners' ability to see each other during the head count.

options.label: D
options.text: The prisoners' inductive reasoning and common knowledge.

multiple-choice.question: Why did the prisoners not leave the island immediately after the content creator's visit?

options.label: A
options.text: They did not understand the content creator's statement.

options.label: B
options.text: They were waiting for more information.

options.label: C
options.text: They were waiting for the night to pass and for each other to leave.

options.label: D
options.text: They were waiting for the content creator to leave the island.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Adria and Bill seeing each other on the first morning after the content creator's visit?

options.label: B
options.text: They were confused and did not know what to do.

options.label: C
options.text: They realized that they were not the only green-eyed people the content creator was referring to.

options.label: D
options.text: They realized that they both had green eyes.

multiple-choice.question: Why did Carl think that Adria and Bill would leave the island on the second night?

options.label: B
options.text: Because they were watching each other.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they realized that they were not the only green-eyed people the content creator was referring to.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they were waiting for Carl to leave the island.

multiple-choice.question: What is the pattern that will repeat no matter how many prisoners are on the island?

options.label: A
options.text: The prisoners will leave the island immediately after the content creator's visit.

options.label: B
options.text: The prisoners will take a certain number of nights to figure out their own eye colors and leave the island.

options.label: C
options.text: The prisoners will stay on the island forever.

options.label: D
options.text: The prisoners will be released from the island by the dictator.

multiple-choice.question: Why did the content creator not tell the prisoners that at least 99 of them had green eyes?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the content creator did not know how many prisoners had green eyes.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the content creator did not want to spare the prisoners 98 days on the island.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the content creator was not allowed to tell the prisoners new information.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the content creator wanted to outsmart the dictator.

multiple-choice.question: What is the implication of the phrase "common knowledge" in the context of the situation on the island?

options.label: A
options.text: It means that everyone on the island knows something.

options.label: B
options.text: It means that everyone on the island knows that everyone else knows something.

options.label: C
options.text: It means that everyone on the island knows that everyone else knows that everyone else knows something.

options.label: D
options.text: It means that everyone on the island knows that everyone else knows that everyone else knows that everyone else knows something.

title: How to make an attractive city

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's main argument about cities?

options.label: A
options.text: Cities are inherently chaotic and can't be improved.

options.label: B
options.text: Cities should be designed to be more scientific and follow certain principles.

options.label: C
options.text: Cities are only beautiful if they are old.

options.label: D
options.text: Cities are a necessary evil and can't be made attractive.

multiple-choice.question: What is the ideal balance between order and chaos in a city, according to the author?

options.label: A
options.text: A city should be completely ordered with no chaos.

options.label: B
options.text: A city should be completely chaotic with no order.

options.label: C
options.text: A city should have a balance between order and chaos.

options.label: D
options.text: A city should have too much order or too much chaos.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Visible life in a city is only important for tourists.

options.label: C
options.text: Visible life in a city is essential for making it attractive.

options.label: D
options.text: Visible life in a city is only important for commercial purposes.

options.label: A
options.text: Buildings should be as tall as possible.

options.label: B
options.text: Buildings should be limited to five stories high.

options.label: C
options.text: Buildings should be limited to ten stories high.

options.label: D
options.text: Buildings should be limited to 20 stories high.

options.label: A
options.text: Local character is not important in a city.

options.label: B
options.text: Local character is only important for historical buildings.

options.label: C
options.text: Local character is essential for making a city attractive.

options.label: D
options.text: Local character is only important for commercial purposes.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Compact cities are essential for making a city attractive.

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: Orientation and mystery are not important in a city.

options.label: B
options.text: Orientation and mystery are only important for tourists.

options.label: C
options.text: Orientation and mystery are essential for making a city attractive.

options.label: D
options.text: Orientation and mystery are only important for commercial purposes.

options.label: B
options.text: Citizens should only provide funding for beautiful cities.

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: How to detect a supernova - Samantha Kuula

multiple-choice.question: How often does a supernova occur in the observable universe?

options.label: B
options.text: Every 25 to 50 years in a galaxy the size and age of the Milky Way

options.label: A
options.text: The large number of stars in the observable universe

options.label: C
options.text: The odds of having the right telescope focused on the right star at the right time

options.label: D
options.text: The distance of the star from Earth

multiple-choice.question: What type of particle travels faster than light and is used to anticipate a supernova before its light reaches Earth?

options.label: C
options.text: The cause of the explosion (nuclear reaction vs. gravitational forces)

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of neutrinos in a supernova explosion?

options.label: A
options.text: They are responsible for the explosion itself

options.label: B
options.text: They interact with the stellar core and cause the explosion

options.label: C
